Students will learn about the following systems:  integumentary, digestive, respiratory, cardiovascular, blood, lymphatic, immune,  musculoskeletal, urinary, reproductive, endocrine, and nervous. Students will gain an  understanding of the functions of each system, analyze related terms, identify abnormal  conditions, describe relevant laboratory tests and treatments and apply their new  knowledge to understanding medical terms in their proper contexts, such as medical  reports and records. This is a very self-directed, fast-paced class for online students,  which will provide you with the tools necessary to read, speak, and understand the  language of medicine in order to effectively communicate in a medical facility. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Music Appreciation
description: Music is part of everyday lives and reflects the spirit of our human condition. To know  and understand music, we distinguish and identify cultures on local and global levels.  This course will provide students with an aesthetic and historical perspective of music,  covering a variety of styles and developments from the Middle Ages through the  Twenty-First Century. Students will acquire basic knowledge and listening skills, making  future music experiences more informed and satisfying. View full syllabus

title: Pathways to Success - High School
description: This CTE course covers ways to help students learn important skills to be successful in both school and life including goal setting, teamwork and collaboration skills, health and wellbeing skills, and planning for a future career. Students will learn the skills needed to navigate in the 21st century including communication, social media, media literacy, and personal finance. This is a CTE Digital class. View full syllabus

title: Psychology
description: The intention of the course is to show you a variety of aspects of psychology and to give  you a small glimpse into what drives human behavior. Since we cannot cover each topic  in depth, the course includes some projects that will require you to dig deeper into some  areas on your own than we are able to in the reading material. At the end of this  course, you will not be able to diagnose a friend with a mental illness or explain your  annoying sibling’s behavior completely, but you may find that you understand some of  their responses to certain situations a little better. You may even find that you have an  interest in pursuing this subject at a more advanced level in future courses.  Above all, remember that no two people are alike and that no theory or psychologist can  predict or explain every behavior. Psychology is known as a “soft science”, because the  research is often based on people’s emotions and their thoughts rather than on things  that are more specifically measurable. View full syllabus

title: Senior Project
description: This course is designed to adapt to any local requirements. Students use a project management based approach to develop their own timeline in completing all the necessary components of their senior project. Students will work in conjunction with local senior project coordinators and mentors in adhering to local senior project requirements and completing their project and presentation. A career-focused project is a prerequisite if the student aims to utilize their Senior Project as a pathway to completing the Career Exploration Plan and Launch Scholarship Program. View full syllabus

title: Sociology
description: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts, principles, and processes relevant to the study of society and everyday life. The course will examine a diverse range of topics pertaining to human behavior and social structure. A primary focus will be developing a sociological perspective through theory and research. Additionally, discussions of culture, development of the self, deviance, social inequality, social institutions, and social change will be explored. Emphasis will be placed on the contemporary American experience, yet making global connections will also be stressed. Parents and students should review the syllabus content carefully prior to enrollment and determine if this content is in alignment with their beliefs, values, or principles. View full syllabus

title: Spanish 1A
description: ¡Bienvenidos a la clase de Español! This is a communicative beginning high-school  level Spanish course that introduces the basics of Spanish grammar and vocabulary. In  this course, students will begin developing Spanish proficiency online through audio,  video, text, and interactive practice activities. Students will read, write, listen, and speak  basic Spanish. View full syllabus This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.

title: Spanish 1B
description: Spanish 1B is the second semester of Spanish. You will build upon what you have  learned in Spanish 1A. You will add to your knowledge of vocabulary and grammar and  you will continue to learn about Hispanic culture. View full syllabus This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.

title: Spanish 2A
description: ¡Bienvenidos a la clase de Español 2! This first semester of Spanish 2 is a  beginner-intermediate course that will build on the foundational structures and  vocabulary learned in first-year Spanish. Throughout this course, you will learn to  express yourself about a variety of topics including school, daily routines, living in and  maintaining an apartment or house, your childhood activities, and family and cultural  traditions and celebrations. You will also learn about various cultural topics focusing on  the country of Spain. You will continue to develop your ability to speak, read, write, and  listen to Spanish both in the present and the preterite and imperfect past tenses  throughout this course. View full syllabus

title: Spanish 2B
description: ¡Bienvenidos a la clase de Español 2! The second semester of Spanish 2 is a  beginner-intermediate course that will build on the foundational structures and  vocabulary learned in the first semester of Spanish 2. Throughout this course, you will  learn to express yourself about a variety of topics including professions, leisure  activities, shopping for food and cooking dishes, describing appropriate clothing for use  in different climates, shopping and paying for items purchased, and illnesses, injuries,  and emergency responses. You will also continue to learn about various cultural topics  focusing on the country of Spain. You will continue to develop your skills in the past  tense while learning to distinguish between the preterite and imperfect past tenses and  applying these tenses to narratives in the past. You will also learn additional structures  and tenses that will allow you to give directions, provide locations, and improve your  fluency and proficiency while speaking and writing in Spanish. View full syllabus

title: Spanish 3A
description: ¡Bienvenidos a la clase de Español 3! This is an advanced Spanish course that will  review concepts from Spanish 1 and 2 and will also introduce advanced vocabulary  topics and grammar concepts including the subjunctive mood and compound verb  tenses among others. Students will continue to develop Spanish proficiency through  audio, video, and text. View full syllabus

title: Spanish 3B
description: ¡Bienvenidos a la clase de Español 3B! This is an advanced Spanish course that will  build on what you have already learned in Spanish 1, 2, and 3A. This course will  continue to build understanding of the subjunctive mood, will introduce the future and  conditional tenses, and will review and deepen understanding of topics learned in  previous courses. Students will continue to develop Spanish proficiency through audio,  video, and text.View full syllabus

title: Speech
description: This course emphasizes the basic principles of effective communication and public speaking skills. Students will present speeches in two different genres (informative and persuasive). Assignments and activities will focus on Idaho Core standards and emphasize listening, speaking, viewing, collaborating, comprehending, presenting, and attaining knowledge and ideas. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. **Both the Informative and Persuasive Speech presentations are required in order for students to be eligible to pass the course, regardless of their overall grade. View full syllabus

title: Exploring STEM Careers - Middle School
description: This course covers a variety of fascinating STEM careers that require skills in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Throughout this course, students will not only learn about different STEM career paths but also learn STEM-specific skills that will help them get a better idea of the types of STEM careers they might enjoy. Students will have the opportunity to complete a variety of STEM-based projects, such as building the tallest paper tower, creating a computer game using code, planning and playing a game based on probability, and more. Towards the end of this course, students will create a STEM-focused career pathway plan that will help them start planning the courses and extracurriculars that want to pursue in high school and beyond. This course meets the First Steps standards and qualifies as a middle school career exploration course.  Link to Syllabus

title: US History 10A
description: This course covers key events, people, and ideas that shaped the United States from early Indigenous civilizations through the 19th century. Students will learn how geography, colonization, revolution, government, and expansion influenced American society. The course explores how different groups—like Indigenous peoples, settlers, enslaved individuals, and immigrants—contributed to and were impacted by historical developments. By the end, students will have a deeper understanding of how the nation was formed and how it changed over time.This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: US History 10B
description: This course covers roughly 1817 through approximately 1910 in United States History.  Students will learn about Manifest Destiny, US Reform Movements, the Civil War,  Reconstruction, and Westward Expansion. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: US History 11A
description: Welcome to U.S. History 11A. This is the first of a two-semester course that aims to give students a general understanding of the political, economic, and social changes within American society from the beginning of the 20th Century (Gilded Age) through World War II. We will be looking at a few primary sources that highlight each era as they are covered. There were fifteen presidents during the years that this course covers and each one is important. However, two of these United States presidents were notably significant and influential and we will study them in some detail. Those presidents are Theodore (Teddy) Roosevelt and his second cousin, Franklin Delano Roosevelt (FDR). This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: US History 11B
description: Welcome to U.S. History 11B. This course covers the Cold War to the Present. Students will learn about the Cold War, the Civil Rights Movement, major changes during the 1960s and 1970, the Vietnam War, the Watergate Scandal, and some of the major events of contemporary America such as 9/11 and the Persian Gulf Wars. They will create presentations, analyze political cartoons, and write stories. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: World History A - High School
description: This course covers early hunter-gatherer communities during the Paleolithic Age to the  Agrarian communities in the New Paleolithic Age. Students will learn about Ancient  River Valley Civilizations and their achievements that helped to develop the civilized  world. They will learn about the social, economical, and political characteristics in  ancient Greece, Rome, the Byzantine Empire, early African and Mesoamerican  civilizations. They will evaluate the role of the Catholic Church during the Middle Ages  and determine the achievements of the Renaissance Era in order to explain how  western society benefited from this Reformation. View full syllabus

title: World History A - Middle School
description: This course covers early hunter-gatherer communities during the Paleolithic Age to the  Agrarian communities in the New Paleolithic Age. Students will learn about Ancient  River Valley Civilizations and their achievements that helped to develop the civilized  world. They will learn about the social, economic, and political characteristics of ancient  Greece, Rome, the Byzantine Empire, early African and Mesoamerican civilizations.  They will evaluate the role of the Catholic Church during the Middle Ages and determine  the achievements of the Renaissance Era in order to explain how western society  benefited from this Reformation. View full syllabus

title: World History B - High School
description: This course covers where World History A leaves off. Students will learn events from the  Renaissance up to the modern-day world. All resources for this course are available  through the online course. View full syllabus.

title: World History B - Middle School
description: This course covers where World History A leaves off. Students will learn events from the  Renaissance up to the modern-day world. All resources for this course are available  through the online course. View full syllabus

title: Intro to Drafting 1B
description: This course covers various concepts used in the design and architecture field. Students will learn about sequential processes to develop an understanding of creating and annotation drawings. They will apply standard rules regarding line types, offset objects, creating layers, and setting up a page for plotting. They will also explore three-dimensional drawing and use coordinating and navigation systems to create them. This is a CTE Digital class. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Career and Life Planning (BSU)
description: Helps students plan and prepare for the life they want after college. Learn how to choose a career path that balances interests, abilities, and values with the realities of the job market. Explore majors, identify steps required to become employable, and build job search skills necessary to achieve goals. *Not a GEM course.View full syllabus

title: Intro to Culinary Arts
description: This course will give you the basic fundamentals to start working in the kitchen and  gaining experience as you explore and establish your talents for cooking and preparing  food in a creative and safe way. In this course, you will cover careers in the food service  industry, basic nutrition, culinary arts safety, kitchen equipment and tools, and important  fundamental skills. There is at least one cooking lab assignment in each unit. This is a CTE Digital class. View full syllabus

title: Sports and Entertainment Marketing
description: In this CTE course, you'll have the opportunity to explore basic marketing principles and delve deeper into the multi-billion dollar sports and entertainment marketing industry. You'll learn about how professional athletes, sports teams, and well known entertainers are marketed as commodities. If you've ever wondered about working in the sports or entertainment industries then this course will introduce you to the fundamentals of such a career. This is a CTE Digital class. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Environmental Science A (NNU)
description: The Dual Credit Environmental Science course is a two semester course equivalent to a college level environmental science course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from Northwest Nazarene University. Students must enroll in both Environmental Science A and Environmental Science B to earn credit from NNU. A study of the issues pertaining to environmental sustainability including topics such as population growth, energy, pollution, and conserving biodiversity. *Not a GEM course.  Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Algebra 1A
description: This course will deepen and extend understanding of linear and exponential  relationships by contrasting them with each other and by applying linear models to data  that exhibit a linear trend, and students engage in methods for analyzing, solving, and  using quadratic functions. The completion of this course will prepare students to  continue on to the second semester of Algebra 1, and then on to Algebra 2 or  Geometry. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Algebra 1B
description: Course Description:  This course will build upon first semester Algebra by exploring statistics and polynomials and will dive deeper into quadratic functions. Students will also broaden their understanding of non-linear systems of equations and rational equations. The completion of this course will prepare students to continue on to Algebra 2 or Geometry. This course is a Quality Matters Certified Course. View full syllabus

title: Algebra 2A
description: This course will build on student’s knowledge of linear, quadratic, and polynomial functions, with extensions on advanced, rational, and radical functions. Students will work with the expressions that define the functions and continue to expand their abilities to model situations and solve equations, which include quadratic equations over the set of complex numbers and solving rational expressions and functions. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Algebra 2B
description: Algebra 2B is the second semester of a two-semester course. This course will build on  student’s knowledge exponential functions, with extensions on polynomials, rational,  and radical functions. Students will work with the expressions that define the functions  and continue to expand their abilities to model situations and solve equations, which  include solving exponential equations using the properties of logarithms. Students will  also work with inferences and conclusions of data. This course aligns to the Idaho Core  State Standards. View full syllabus

title: Anatomy and Physiology A
description: Anatomy and Physiology A is the first in a sequential two semester course that focuses on the structure and functions of the human body. Each of the human body systems will be studied with an emphasis on structure and function, developmental changes from infancy to old age, and common problems and diseases. You will participate in several activities including virtual labs and simulations, home science lab investigations, class discussions, and course projects. These activities require that you have met prerequisites of Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology. Whether you enroll to learn more about how your body works, or you are interested in continuing your education in Health Professions, this course is designed to help you meet the requirements for a third year of high school science and is structured to appeal to a wide variety of mature high school students.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus.   Prerequisites:  Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology

title: Anatomy and Physiology B
description: Anatomy and Physiology B is the second in a sequential two semester course that focuses on the structure and functions of the human body. Each of the human body systems will be studied with an emphasis on structure and function, developmental changes from infancy to old age, and common problems and diseases. You will participate in several activities including virtual labs and simulations, home science lab investigations, class discussions, and course projects. These activities require that you have met prerequisites of Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology. Whether you enroll to learn more about how your body works, or you are interested in continuing your education in Health Professions, this course is designed to help you meet the requirements for a third year of high school science and is structured to appeal to a wide variety of mature high school students.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full Syllabus.  Required Prerequisites:  Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology

title: Biology A
description: You will work through coursework, labs, and activities covering the scientific method, organic compounds, cell structure, genetics, biotechnology, and biological change. Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Biology B
description: Biology B builds on the concepts you learned in Biology A. You will investigate natural selection and apply it to populations, history and diversity of life. You will explore how life on Earth displays both unity and diversity. In addition, you will learn about ecology from communities, populations, and the biosphere. Lastly, you will explore how humans have impacted planet Earth. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Fundamentals of Health Professions (LCSC)
description: This CTE course provides an in-depth exploration of key concepts essential for a career in healthcare. Students will begin with an introduction to healthcare as well as healthcare roles and professional responsibilities, learning the foundational skills required to thrive in the field. Emphasis will be placed on effective communication, including cultural awareness, to enhance patient care in diverse settings. Students will examine wellness practices, safety protocols, and emergency preparedness to promote health and prevent harm. The course will also cover essential medical mathematics, terminology, and the organization of the human body, which will provide the foundation for a thorough study of anatomy and physiology. The anatomy and physiology units will progressively explore the structure and function of the human body, culminating in a comprehensive understanding of how body systems work together to maintain health and respond to illness.     This one-semester course meets Idaho standards for CTE - Health Professions as well as General High School Health Standards.     Fundamentals of Health Professions introduces you to the healthcare industry by providing the background required for many jobs in healthcare and a basic understanding of human anatomy and physiology. The course serves as the prerequisite for students planning to enter the CNA, basic EMT, pharmacy technology, or other health care programs. The skills learned in this course are transferable to many health occupations.   This is NOT a GEM course.    View full syllabus **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration.

title: Dual Credit Concepts of Biology A (CWI)
description: The Dual Credit Biology course is a two-semester course equivalent to a college-level biology course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from the College of Western Idaho. Students must enroll in both DC BIO A and DC BIO B to earn credit from CWI.  This is an introductory course for non-science majors that provides a broad survey of biology by exploring the principles and processes that apply to living systems, including current biological issues.  This course is a GEM Scientific Ways of Knowing course.    Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus   Required Prerequisites:  HS Biology + 1 year other HS year of Science.

title: Dual Credit Concepts of Biology B (CWI)
description: The Dual Credit Biology course is a two semester course equivalent to a college level biology course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from College of Western Idaho. Students must enroll in both DC BIO A and DC BIO B to earn credit from CWI.  This is an introductory course for non-science majors that provides a broad survey of biology by exploring the principles and processes that apply to living systems, including current biological issues.  This course is a GEM Scientific Ways of Knowing course.  Idaho Lab High School Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus  Required Prerequisites:  HS Biology + 1 year other HS year of Science.

title: Career Math A
description: In this third-year level Career Math A course, you will cover topics that will help you become familiar with math used in careers. Students will review and master topics from whole numbers, fractions and decimals, real numbers, measurement, rates and ratios, geometry and statistics. They will discuss and complete small projects that involve the topics listed above as they relate to different careers. View full syllabus. Prerequisites (required prerequisites): Algebra and Geometry. *Please note: This class is not NCAA approved and should not be taken by students who intend to become college athletes.

title: Career Math B
description: In this third-year level Career Math B course, you will cover topics that will help you become familiar with math used in careers. Students will review and master topics from equations, polynomials, factoring, functions, systems for equations, rationals, radical and quadratic equations, and exponential and logarithmic functions. They will discuss and complete projects that involve the topics listed above as they relate to different careers. View full syllabus. Prerequisites (required prerequisites): Algebra and Geometry. *Please note: This class is not NCAA approved and should not be taken by students who intend to become college athletes.

title: Dual Credit Eng 12A/Eng 101 (CEI)
description: **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration.  Students will be introduced to critical reading and writing challenges including pre-writing strategies, invention, revision and editing. Throughout the course, students will produce written texts that show unity and coherence, develop and support a central idea, and demonstrate organization. Keyboarding skills are strongly recommended.  This is a GEM: Written Communications course. View full syllabus   Placement Guidelines (suggested prerequisites):  Strong keyboarding skills recommended  Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Proof of prerequisite scores of:  ACT score of (English 19-24) or  SAT score of (ERW 500-620) or  Accuplacer score of (250+)

title: College Prep Math A
description: In this third-year level College Math Prep A course, you will cover topics that will help you become college math ready. Students will review and master topics from whole numbers, fractions and decimals, real numbers, measurement, rates and ratios, geometry and statistics. They will discuss and complete small projects that involve the topics listed above. View full syllabus Placement Guidelines (pre-requisites): Algebra and Geometry Please note: This class is not NCAA approved and should not be taken by students who intend to become college athletes.

title: Dual Credit Eng 12B/Eng 102 (CEI)
description: This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college. Provides instruction in critical reading and writing of expository and argumentative prose, including summaries, analysis, and research. The class will emphasize academic inquiry and research as well as explore issues from multiple perspectives. Teaches careful reasoning, argumentation, and rhetorical awareness of purpose, audience, and genre with a focus on critically evaluating, effectively integrating, and properly documenting sources.  This is a GEM: Written Communications course. View full syllabus Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Students registering for college credit need to provide evidence of a transcripted ENGL 101 credit with a grade of ‘C’ or better. Documentation of this can be sent in along with the student's registration.

title: College Prep Math B
description: In this third-year level College Math Prep B course, you will cover topics that will help you become college math ready. Students will review and master topics from equations, polynomials, factoring, functions, systems for equations, rationals, radical and quadratic equations, and exponential and logarithmic functions. They will discuss and complete small projects that involve the topics listed above. View full syllabus Prerequisites (required pre-requisites): Algebra and Geometry Please note: This class is not NCAA approved and should not be taken by students who intend to become college athletes.

title: Dual Credit Human Biology A (NNU)
description: Dual Credit Human Biology course is a two semester course equivalent to a college level course that focuses on the structure and functions of the human body. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from Northwest Nazarene University. Students must enroll in both Human Biology A and Human Biology B to earn credit from NNU. Each of the human body systems will be studied with an emphasis on structure and function, developmental changes from infancy to old age, and common problems and diseases. You will participate in several activities including virtual labs and simulations, home science lab investigations, class discussions, and course projects. These activities require that you have met prerequisites of Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology. Whether you enroll to learn more about how your body works, or you are interested in continuing your education in Health Professions, this course is designed to help you meet the requirements for a third year of high school science and is structured to appeal to a wide variety of mature high school students. *Not a GEM course.  Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus   Prerequisites:  Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology

title: Dual Credit Human Biology B (NNU)
description: This is the second semester of a one-year Anatomy and Physiology course that focuses on the structure and functions of the human body. Students must successfully complete both “A” & “B” sessions of the IDLA class to earn college credit. Each of the human body systems will be studied with an emphasis on structure and function, developmental changes from infancy to old age, and common problems and diseases. You will participate in several activities including virtual labs and simulations, home science lab investigations, class discussions, and course projects. These activities require that you have met prerequisites of Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology. Whether you enroll to learn more about how your body works, or you are interested in continuing your education in Health Professions, this course is designed to help you meet the requirements for a third year of high school science and is structured to appeal to a wide variety of mature high school students. *Not a GEM course.  Idaho High Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus  Prerequisites:  Algebra I, Physical Science, and Biology

title: Dual Credit Concepts of Biology A (CSI)
description: The Dual Credit Concepts of Biology course is a two-semester course equivalent to a college-level biology course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from the College of Southern Idaho. Students must enroll in both DC BIO A and DC BIO B to earn credit from CSI.  This is an introductory course for non-science majors. The course will provide an introduction to the principles and processes that apply to living systems including a broad range of current biological issues. It meets for an equivalent of 5 contact hours per week with a minimum of 2 contact hours devoted to laboratory/investigative activities.    Idaho Lab High School Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, and specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate, or test scientific principles or concepts.  This is a GEM: Scientific Ways of Knowing course. View Syllabus Here

title: Dual Credit Calculus A (CSI)
description: The Dual Calculus course is a two semester course equivalent to a college level calculus course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from College of Southern Idaho. Students must enroll in both  DC Calculus A and DC Calculus B to earn credit from CSI.  Over the course of both semesters (DC Calculus A and DC Calculus B) the course will cover algebraic and  transcendental functions, rates of change, limits, continuity, differentiation of algebraic,  trigonometric, exponential, logarithmic, and hyperbolic functions and their inverses,  L’Hospital’s rule, differentials, various applications of differentiation including  optimization, motion, and related-rate problems, definite and indefinite integrals, area  between curves, volumes of solids, and various other applications of integration.  MATH 170 is the first course in the calculus sequence, and is the foundational course  for most of the mathematics courses studied at the university level. This course is  designed for students majoring in the mathematical and physical sciences, engineering,  or mathematics education. The mastery of calculus requires well-developed skills, clear  conceptual understanding, and the ability to think critically.  This is a GEM: Mathematical Ways of Knowing course. View full syllabus   Prerequisites (required pre-requisites):  Students enrolling in MATH 170 at CSI should have completed a Precalculus course, and have demonstrated qualification in one of the following ways:   • By scoring at least 52 on the trigonometry section of the COMPASS test.  • By scoring at least 76 on the ALEKS test.  • By scoring at least 29 on the ACT mathematics test.

title: Dual Credit Chemistry A (BSU)
description: The Dual Credit Chemistry course is a two semester course equivalent to a college level chemistry course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from Boise State University. Students must enroll in both DC Chem A and DC Chem B to earn credit from BSU.  Acquaint students with chemistry and its relationship to other fields of study and modern life. This is a dual credit class for non-science majors. This class will not count towards a STEM degree. It is intended for students wanting to register for university credit. This is a GEM: Scientific Way of Knowing course.  Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the High School lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts.View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Chemistry B (BSU)
description: This is the second semester of a one-year Dual Credit Chemistry course. Students must successfully complete both “A” & “B” sessions of the IDLA class to earn college credit.  Acquaint students with chemistry and its relationship to other fields of study and modern life. This is a dual credit class for non-science majors. This class will not count towards a STEM degree. It is intended for students wanting to register for university credit. This is a GEM: Scientific Way of Knowing course.    Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Idaho Science & Aerospace Scholars (BSU)
description: **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college. You must use the College Registration information found in this syllabus and register through the college separately. This syllabus includes policies for both Idaho Digital Learning Alliance and the cooperating university. Please be sure to review the entire syllabus.   Course Description:  In this course, students will explore the early history of astronomy and delve into the latest projects and technologies essential for extraterrestrial missions. Students will gain insights into the methods of reaching extraterrestrial destinations, ensuring sustainable life in those environments, and safely returning to Earth. Through collaborative efforts, students will design a crewed mission, combining existing and speculative technologies, envisioning a future interstellar expedition. *Not a GEM course.  Upon successful completion of the course, the highest performing students may also be selected to participate in an expense-paid, week-long resident academy at Boise State University and NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in California. Become an Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholar by filling out the online application!  To apply to become an Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholar, you must:  Be a U.S. Citizen and Idaho resident  Be a high school junior with an interest in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics  Have a minimum GPA of 2.7  Be at least 16 years of age and have parental permission  Commit to all aspects of the ISAS program  Have internet access and e-mail (home, school, or public library)  Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Earth Science A - High School
description: Earth Science A introduces students to the scientific exploration of our planet.Through observation and experimentation, students explore Earth's past, present, and predict its future. The content covers the scientific process, Earth's composition and history, plate tectonics, geological activities, surface changes, and the connection between Earth and human activities. The course engages students with readings, labs, and practical application of concepts to real-world challenges.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus.

title: Earth Science A - Middle School
description: This course covers the first semester of Earth science. Students will explore Earth’s minerals and rocks, plate tectonics, geologic activity, and Earth’s history. Students will perform hands-on and virtual laboratory assignments. They will model weathering and erosion, analyze natural disasters and make predictions, utilize Google Earth to explore Earth’s surface, and create their own model representing rock layers and index fossils.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus.

title: Earth Science B - High School
description: Earth Science B is the second semester course designed to expose the student to the scientific study of the Earth. Students will learn how observation and experimentation  are used to gain knowledge about the Earth's past and present and used in making predictions about Earth's future. The course emphasis is on astronomy, meteorology,  and hydrology. The course will include outside readings, labs and the application of learned material to everyday problems.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Geometry A
description: Students will learn the concepts of basic geometry, transformations and congruency, proofs of theorems, dilations and similarity, and triangle similarity. They will practice these mathematical concepts in a variety of forms and applications. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.Students will employ the standards of mathematical practice as they work through course material. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Geometry B
description: This course covers the second semester of a two semester Geometry course that aligns to the Idaho Core standards for high school mathematics. Students will learn concepts of Geometry that include coordinate geometry, right triangle trigonometry, circles, volume, conics and modeling. They will practice these mathematical concepts in a variety of forms and applications. Students will employ the standards of mathematical practice as they work through course material. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View syllabus

title: Math 8A
description: This is the first semester of a two semester Middle School Math course that aligns to the  Idaho Content standards for middle school mathematics. This course will dive into the  concepts of input-output relationships, linear functions, linear equations, systems of  equations and their applications, exponents, and exponential equations and their  applications. We will connect these concepts to real-world applications. Students will  practice these mathematical concepts in a variety of forms and applications. Students  will employ the standards of mathematical practice as they work through course  material. View full syllabus.

title: Math 8B
description: This is the second semester of a two semester Math 8 course that aligns to the Idaho  Content standards for middle school mathematics. This course will dive into the concepts  of transformations, similar and congruent figures, special relationships in geometric  figures, Pythagorean Theorem, volume, and patterns in data. We will connect these  concepts to real-world applications. Students will practice these mathematical concepts  in a variety of forms and applications. Students will employ the standards of  mathematical practice as they work through course material. View full syllabus

title: Physical Science A - High School
description: Physical Science A explores primary concepts of Physics in the real world as we know it. You will be exposed to exciting concepts of motions and forces, acceleration, lab safety, metrics, simple machines, energy, electricity, magnetism, waves, sound, light, and more. You will experience virtual simulations of these concepts as well as try your hand at some hands-on labs to explore in real life. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. title: Physical Science B - High School
description: Physical Science B is the second semester course designed to expose the student to the fundamentals of the nature of matter and the laws and theories that govern chemistry. In this course, students will spend time studying the building blocks of matter, how atoms form compounds, chemical reactions, and acid base theory. This course meets the Idaho State Standards for Physical Science.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts.  The standards covered in this course are aligned to meet grades 9-12 physical science standards. Middle school students may find this course more rigorous than a traditional middle school course. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

description: Physical Science B is the second semester course designed to expose the student to the fundamentals of the nature of matter and the laws and theories that govern chemistry. This course meets the Idaho State Standards for Physical Science.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts.  The standards covered in this course are aligned to meet grades 9-12 physical science standards. Middle school students may find this course more rigorous than a traditional middle school course. View full syllabus

title: Physics A
description: This course covers physics the study of the world around us and the laws of nature that govern that world. The first semester of physics will cover the topics the mathematics used in Physics, motion (one dimensional and projectile motion), forces, Newton’s Laws, gravity, circular motion, collisions and momentum, work and energy. This is an algebra-based introductory physics class. A student who has completed geometry will adapt well to this course work.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus  Required Prerequisites:  2 years HS Science and Algebra 2.

title: Physics B
description: This course covers the second semester of physics will cover a whole set of new topics, using the skills mastered in the first semester. Students will learn a whole set of new topics, using the skills mastered in the first semester. The major units will be waves, heat, electricity and magnetism. The study of light will include reflection, refraction, and lenses, while electricity will contain subtopics of static electricity (Coulomb's Law),  current flow using Ohm's Law and series and parallel circuit design, and capacitors.  Again, a working knowledge of algebra and geometry will aid the student at being successful in physics! Prerequisite: Physics A, two years high school science, Algebra II.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Environmental Science B (NNU)
description: This is the second semester of a one-year Environmental Science course. Students must successfully complete both “A” & “B” sessions of the IDLA class to earn college credit. A study of the issues pertaining to environmental sustainability including topics such as population growth, energy, pollution, and conserving biodiversity. *Not a GEM course.  Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts.   View full syllabus

title: Astronomy
description: Astronomy is designed to expose the student to the scientific study of the Earth and the known universe. Students will learn how experimentation and observation are used to gain knowledge about the Earth, the Solar System and the Universe. Topics to be covered are the history of Astronomy, our Solar System, the Sun-Earth-Moon relationships, Light, Stars, Galaxies, Space Exploration and current scientific beliefs about the history of the formation of the Universe. This course will incorporate labs and activities for every unit to deepen student understanding of abstract topics. This course does satisfy the state requirement for credit in a lab science.   Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Precalculus 1: Algebra (CWI)
description: This course includes fundamental concepts of algebra, equations and inequalities, functions and graphs, systems of equations and inequalities, and polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions. View full syllabus  This is a GEM: Mathematical Ways of Knowing course.   **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration.  Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Algebra II

title: Dual Credit Precalculus 2: Trigonometry (CSI)
description: This course covers right triangle and circular function approaches to trigonometry, graphs of trig functions, trig identities, conditional equations, right and non-right triangle applications of trigonometry, inverse trig functions, trigonometry of complex numbers including DeMoivre's Theorem, polar coordinates and equations, parametric equations. *Not a GEM course. View full syllabus   Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Prior to enrolling in this course, you must verify successful completion of Math 143 College Algebra with a grade of A, B, or C, or you must take the ALEKS, ACT or SAT test and meet the specified cut-off score for enrollment of at least 26 on the ACT or 600 on the SAT.  **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college.

title: Dual Credit Precalculus 2: Trigonometry (CWI)
description: This course covers right triangle and circular function approaches to trigonometry, graphs of trigonometry functions, trigonometry identities, conditional equations, right and non-right triangle applications of trigonometry, inverse trigonometry functions, trigonometry of complex numbers, including DeMoivre's Theorem, polar coordinates and equations, and parametric equations. *Not a GEM course. View full syllabus   Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  MATH 143 with a minimum grade of C or equivalent placement test score or PERM/INST. **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college.

title: Precalculus 2: Trigonometry
description: Trigonometry is designed to be taken after College Algebra in preparation for higher  level courses like calculus. You will focus on trigonometry, including right triangles and  circular function approaches, identities, graphs of trigonometric functions, conics, and  polar coordinates. This is NOT a college course, please see DC Trigonometry for a  concurrent credit option. View full syllabus

title: Zoology
description: Zoology is a one-semester science elective that focuses on animals and their habitats. You will learn about the wide variety of animals present on Earth and how they adapt to Earth's many environments. You will also investigate the anthropogenic impacts on biodiversity and propose possible solutions to mitigate those impacts.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course DOES NOT fulfill the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho. This course is considered an elective science course. View full syllabus

title: Intro to Drafting 1A
description: Combining precision, creativity, and problem-solving with simple math and drafting concepts, this class is perfect for anybody curious about architecture, engineering, or even how drafting skills and design thinking can set you up to become the next big CEO or famous innovator! In this project-based course, students will master the fundamentals of hand drafting - no special software or apps are required. From floor plans to 3D sketches, students will bring their ideas to life while gaining a deeper understanding of the spaces and objects they encounter every day. Rather than memorizing concepts for multiple-choice quizzes, students will apply their knowledge and skills to solve real-world problems! View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Families, Community, Culture (ISU)
description: Examination of interactions among school, family, community, and culture as a basis for  reflecting on the social contexts of learning. Satisfies Objective 9 of the General  Education Objectives. GEM course: Social & Behavioral Ways of Knowing   View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Education and Schooling in the U.S. (ISU)
description: This course provides a survey of historical, sociological, and political issues related to  public education and the system of schooling in the United States.  Students will explore primary and secondary sources and develop insight into how U.S.  educational history affects society today. They will develop critical thinking skills to  interpret historical events and cite evidence for the purpose of developing historical  hypotheses and supplemental essay support for those hypotheses.  This course meets GEM Objective #6: Social and Behavioral Ways of Knowing. Upon  completion of a course in this category, students are able to demonstrate at least four  (4) of the following competencies.  1. Demonstrate knowledge of the theoretical and conceptual frameworks of a  particular Social Science discipline.  2. Develop an understanding of self and the world by examining the dynamic  interaction of individuals, groups, and societies as they shape and are shaped by  history, culture, institutions, and ideas.  3. Utilize Social Science approaches, such as research methods, inquiry, or  problem-solving, to examine the variety of perspectives about human  experiences.  4. Evaluate how reasoning, history, or culture informs and guides individual, civic,  or global decisions.  5. Understand and appreciate similarities and differences among and between  individuals, cultures, or societies across space and time.  At the end of this course, your instructor will evaluate if you successfully met these  standards. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Academic Success Topics (BSU)
description: Focuses on the development of skills, attitudes and behaviors associated with academic success in college. Selected topics may include: transition to university life for specific groups of students (such as veterans, athletes, international students, high school students, and non-traditional students); exploration of campus resources and opportunities; time management and basic study skills; and math success strategies. *Not a GEM course. View full syllabus

title: AP Statistics A
description: This is the first semester of a two semester AP Statistics course. This course will dive  into the concepts of univariate data, bivariate data, conducting studies and experiments,  probability and random variables, binomial and geometric sampling and sampling  distributions. We will connect these concepts to real-world applications. Students will  practice these mathematical concepts in a variety of forms and applications. Students  will employ the standards of mathematical practice as they work through course  material. View full syllabus  Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Students enrolling in the course should have completed Algebra 2 or Integrated Math 3.

title: AP Statistics B
description: This course covers concepts of inference; inference for means and proportions,  inference for chi-squared and inference for slope. We will connect these concepts to  real-world applications. Students will practice these mathematical concepts in a variety  of forms and applications. Students will employ the standards of mathematical practice  as they work through course material. View full syllabus

title: Spanish 1B - HYB
description: Spanish 1B is the second semester of Spanish. You will build upon what you have learned in Spanish 1A. You will add to your knowledge of vocabulary and grammar and you will continue to learn about Hispanic culture.  Unit Titles:   Unit 1: El Tiempo Libre - In this unit, you're going to learn how to talk about a variety of activities that you do in your free time. You will also learn how to say which of those activities you like to do and which ones you don't like to do.   Unit 2: Los Deportes - In this lesson, you're going to learn how to talk about sports as well as what you and your family are going to do this weekend.   Unit 3: La Comida - In this lesson, you're going to learn to talk about doing things with others. You're also going to learn how to talk about food.   Unit 4: La Salud - In this unit, you're going to learn how to talk about what your cafeteria serves and how to talk about when you eat. You will also learn how to talk about the different food groups and what you should (not) eat in order to stay healthy.   Unit 5: Las Compras - In this unit, you're going to learn how to order in a restaurant and how to talk about going shopping in a supermarket.   Unit 6: La Ropa - In this unit, you're going to learn how to talk about what you wear in different seasons and weather and you will also learn how to make purchases and negotiate a price while shopping.   Unit 7: La Ciudad - In this lesson, you're going to learn to talk about different places in your community and different types of transportation.   Unit 8: Las Vacaciones - In this lesson, you're going to learn how to talk about what you (and other people) are doing while on vacation. You will also learn to talk about how you prepare for travel.   Prerequisites: Spanish 1A   Compatibility: This course is Chromebook compatible.   Required textbooks and resources:  There is no textbook required for this class. All required resources are available through the online course.  Speakers/earphones and a microphone are required to participate in our voice assignments and to communicate online in Spanish with your classmates. Each unit contains graphics and sound.

title: Chemistry A
description: Chemistry is the study of the composition, structure, and properties of matter and the changes it undergoes. Matter is all the “stuff” around us. In this first semester class you will learn about atomic structure, physical and chemical change, chemical bonding, naming compounds, percentage composition and molecular geometry. Since chemistry is a laboratory based course, each unit will include a lab simulation and/or a kitchen lab experience. This course fulfills the Lab Science requirement by the State of Idaho.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus  Required Prerequisites:  2 years HS Science, Algebra 1

title: Chemistry B
description: The second semester of chemistry will cover a whole set of new topics, using the skills mastered in the first semester. The major units will be Stoichiometry, nuclear reactions, reaction rates, acids, bases and salts and thermochemistry. Again, a working knowledge of algebra and geometry will aid the student at being successful in Chemistry! This course fulfills the Lab Science requirement by the State of Idaho.  Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

title: Integrated Math 1A
description: This course expands the mathematics students learned in middle grades. Students will  extend their understanding in linear relationships, exponential models, and systems of  linear equations. They will complete activities that will formalize their knowledge in the  areas of both linear and exponential models. Students will be prepared to enter into  Integrated Math 1B after taking this course. View full syllabus

title: Integrated Math 1B
description: This course is designed to extend the mathematics students learned in middle grades  and Integrated Math 1A. Students will extend their understanding in descriptive  statistics, the concepts of basic geometry, proofs of theorems, transformations and  triangle congruence and similarity. Students will be prepared to enter into Integrated  Math II A after taking this course. View full syllabus

title: Japanese 1A
description: This is the first course in a two-course sequence and focuses on the most widely used  Japanese syllabic writing system (Hiragana) and greetings and phrases used in  everyday communication and contemporary Japanese cultures. Lessons are built upon  familiar topics such as self, family, school, and friends to provide meaningful contexts to  develop everyday conversation skills. Each lesson is designed to help students learn  Hiragana gradually through decoding words and reading to speak conversational  expressions. The course includes audio and video learning objects to demonstrate  native Japanese speaker's pronunciation, which supports students in building their  interpersonal and interpretive fluency in Japanese. View full syllabus

title: Japanese 1B
description: This is the second course in a two-course sequence. While it continues focusing on  practical everyday communication skills and contemporary Japanese culture, the course  introduces the second widely used Japanese syllabic writing system, katakana. Lessons  are built upon familiar topics such as self, family, school, and friends to provide  meaningful contexts to develop everyday conversation skills. Each lesson is designed to  help students learn katakana gradually as students work to master the first syllabic  system hiragana through decoding words and reading to speak conversational  expressions. The course includes audio and video learning objects to demonstrate  native Japanese speaker's pronunciation, which supports students in building their  interpersonal and interpretive fluency in Japanese. It is also designed for students to  experience and appreciate the third writing system, kanji. View the full syllabus

title: Precalculus 1: Algebra
description: This advanced algebra class covers functions (linear, polynomial, rational, logarithmic,  exponential), sequences and series, and systems of equations. This is NOT a college  course, please see DC College Algebra A for a concurrent credit option. View full syllabus  Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Geometry and Algebra II.

title: Computer Science Discoveries - Middle School
description: This course introduces students to Computer Science as a vehicle for problem solving,  communication, and personal expression. Students will learn to create websites with the  Code.org Web Lab and will program in Javascript using the Code.org Game Lab  platform. They will collaborate with their peers to propose apps that solve problems and  to create games.  This course serves as a prerequisite to all high school CS and IT pathways. It is  equivalent to Exploring Computer Science. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Introduction to Art (BSU)
description: This course is an introduction to the basic language of Visual Art. title: Dual Credit Medical Terminology (LCSC)
description: This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college.  This CTE course provides students with a working knowledge of the language of medicine. This includes combining of roots, prefixes, and suffixes to form medical terms; linking medical terms, anatomy, and physiology in order to effectively communicate in a medical facility. *Not a GEM course. This course is a college-level course that uses a college adopted textbook, content and assessments that may discuss sensitive issues. Parents and students should review the syllabus content carefully prior to enrollment and determine if this content is in alignment with their beliefs, values or principles. title: Dual Credit Development and Individual Differences (ISU)
description: This course examines developmental characteristics of pre-k through grade 12 students  and corresponding educational practices for each age group. Students interested in  early childhood, elementary and/or secondary education acquire competency for  adjacent and specific age groups they may teach. This is a GEM: Social & Behavioral Ways of Knowing.  View full syllabus Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  For Seniors: B- or better in Junior English OR ACT score of 18+ in ELA OR SAT score of 25+ in Reading  For Juniors: B- or better in Sophomore English AND recommendation of English teacher  C

title: Math 7B
description: This is the second semester of a two semester Math 7 course that aligns to the Idaho Standards for seventh grade mathematics. This course will dive deeper into concepts in geometry, statistics and probability and will connect those concepts to real-world applications. Students will practice these mathematical concepts in a variety of forms and applications. Students will employ the standards of mathematical practice as they work through course material. View full syllabus

title: English 7B
description: This course covers how to evaluate and write the different types of informational writing, arguments, and narratives. Students will learn how to preserve academic integrity in their work by citing sources as well as how to identify reputable sources. They will also gather and evaluate data and research to use in their own informational writing. Then, they will take those skills and use them to evaluate and create a persuasive speech. Lastly, they will learn how to evaluate and write a narrative. They will complete an expository essay, a persuasive essay, a persuasive speech with a visual component, and a narrative writing piece. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Fundamentals of Health Professions (ISU)
description: This CTE course provides an in-depth exploration of key concepts essential for a career in healthcare. Students will begin with an introduction to healthcare as well as healthcare roles and professional responsibilities, learning the foundational skills required to thrive in the field. Emphasis will be placed on effective communication, including cultural awareness, to enhance patient care in diverse settings. Students will examine wellness practices, safety protocols, and emergency preparedness to promote health and prevent harm. The course will also cover essential medical mathematics, terminology, and the organization of the human body, which will provide the foundation for a thorough study of anatomy and physiology. The anatomy and physiology units will progressively explore the structure and function of the human body, culminating in a comprehensive understanding of how body systems work together to maintain health and respond to illness.     This one-semester course meets Idaho standards for CTE - Health Professions as well as General High School Health Standards.     Fundamentals of Health Professions introduces you to the healthcare industry by providing the background required for many jobs in healthcare and a basic understanding of human anatomy and physiology. The course serves as the prerequisite for students planning to enter the CNA, basic EMT, pharmacy technology, or other health care programs. The skills learned in this course are transferable to many health occupations.  This is NOT a GEM course.  View full syllabus **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration.  Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Sophomore, 2.5 GPA and higher.

title: Dual Credit Certified Nursing Assistant A (LCSC)
description: This is the first semester of a year-long course that includes online classroom instruction, hands on learning in a skills lab, and clinical experience. The course prepares the student to provide basic nursing care to clients under the supervision of a licensed nurse. Successful completion with a minimum passing grade of 80% or better, of both A and B semesters, qualifies the student to take the Nursing Assistant skills and written examinations which are required for placement on the Idaho Nursing Assistant Registry. This course is a college-level course that uses a college adopted textbook, content and assessments that may discuss sensitive issues. Parents and students should review the syllabus content carefully prior to enrollment and determine if this content is in alignment with their beliefs, values or principles. *Not a GEM course. View full syllabus   Prerequisites (required prerequisites):  Have passed with at least 80%:  DC Fundamentals for Health Professions  DC Medical Terminology

title: Dual Credit Introduction to Programming (CSI)
description: In this course, students will build the knowledge necessary to construct solutions to problems using the concepts underlying most programming languages, including variables, conditional statements, loops, and functions. Emphasis will be placed on problem decomposition, research techniques, and best practices for generating well-documented, reusable code. This course is part of a 3-course program at CSI. Students who take all 3 courses will receive a technical certificate. The three courses are Dual Credit Intro to Cybersecurity (CSI), Dual Credit Intro to Networking (CSI) and this course. Courses may be taken in any order. *Not a GEM course. View full syllabus

title: Keyboarding - High School - FX
description: Keyboarding - High School is a course designed with the flexibility to help students complete their coursework at their own pace and schedule. This course has four modules, which include: coursework (including computer and teacher-graded assignments), discussion-based assessments (a meeting with your teacher), and module exams. There is no high-stakes final exam; just shorter incremental exams in each module, two of which must be scheduled with a proctor.  While other Flex courses contain pre-tests that allow students to test out of additional practice, this class does not have additional practice due to the nature of the computer application work assigned.  This course is designed to teach students the essential skill of touch-typing using modern tools and interactive lessons. By leveraging the Typesy platform, students will progressively build their typing speed, accuracy, and fluency through guided practice, structured drills, and engaging activities. Emphasis is placed on ergonomics, efficient typing techniques, and practical applications such as professional communication and document creation. View full syllabus

title: American Sign Language 1A
description: This course covers grammar, vocabulary and culture for beginning American Sign  Language (ASL). American Sign Language is a visual and gestural language that is  established with its own structure. ASL is a distinct language and is associated with  Deaf Culture. Students will learn to sign and use basic signs and phrases. Signing skills  will include: signing about home and family, using signs to show events or sign short  stories, signing effectively with others in basic conversation, and learning about the  culture related to the development of ASL and the deaf community. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus.

title: American Sign Language 1B
description: This course covers continued use of grammar, vocabulary, and culture for beginning American Sign Language (ASL). This is a second-semester course and builds on skills learned in ASL 1A. American Sign Language is a visual and gestural language that is established with its own structure. ASL is a distinct language and is associated with Deaf Culture. Students will continue learning basic signs and grammar to effectively communicate with the Deaf. Students learn to sign and understand basic words and phrases. Students will also learn about notable figures in deaf history, and improve their understanding of the deaf experience. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus.

title: World Geography - High School
description: This course covers physical and human geography for all regions of the world.  Students will learn about North America, Middle America, South America, Europe,  Africa, Asia, Oceania and Antarctica. They will use maps to identify various locations  including countries, regions, and geographical features as well as create projects  sharing cultural practices in different parts of the world. View full syllabus

title: World Geography - Middle School
description: This course covers physical and human geography for all regions of the world. Students will learn about North America, Middle America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Oceania and Antarctica. They will use maps to identify various locations including countries, regions, and geographical features as well as create projects sharing cultural practices in different parts of the world. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Psychology (CSI)
description: This survey course is an introduction to psychology. Psychology is the scientific study of thinking, emotion, and behavior. This course introduces students to the diverse research areas of psychology such as psychobiology, motivation, learning, cognitive and social processes, personality, and abnormality, emphasizing empirical findings of the discipline.  This course is a college-level course with content and assessments that may discuss sensitive issues, such as male and female physical development during teenage years and relationships. Parents and students should review the syllabus content carefully prior to enrollment and determine if this content is in alignment with their beliefs, values, and principles.  This course is a GEM Social and Behavioral Ways of Knowing course.   View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Psychology (CWI)
description: This survey course is an introduction to psychology. Psychology is the scientific study of thinking, emotion, and behavior.
