title: Integrated Math 2A
description: This course will introduce the concepts of quadratic equations as well as strengthen  understanding of radicals and complex numbers. Students will learn how to solve  complex equations using a variety of methods and will learn how these equations apply  to real life. View full syllabus

title: Integrated Math 2B
description: This course will continue developing skills with functions as well as build upon previous  knowledge of probability and geometric concepts. Students will learn about the  relationships that exist in various geometric shapes and will be introduced to proofs as a  way of showing those relationships. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Entrepreneurship (CWI)
description: This CTE course is for students who are considering running their own business.  Students will be introduced to the challenges of opening, operating, financing, and  marketing a successful small business. This course is designed to provide students with  an understanding of the underlying beliefs and assumptions which drive the behaviors  entrepreneurs need to succeed. This is a CTE Digital class. *Not a GEM course. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Speech (CEI)
description: This is a course in oral communication that emphasizes the theory and practice of informative group speaking, logical argumentation, persuasion, negotiation, small group discussion, listening, and interpersonal communication with an emphasis on applications in the workplace. This is a GEM: Oral Communication course. View full syllabus **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration.

title: Everyone Can Create with iPads
description: This course covers creative expression through video, photography, music, and drawing on an iPad. Students will learn to explore personal creativity and expression through a variety of projects. They will learn how to create logos, original music, digital photography, and video stories all on an iPad. Students may request to borrow an iPad from IDLA or use their own to complete the coursework. Students completing this class are able to participate in a free iPad summer camp offered in July (see https://idla.org/programs/ecc/ for more information). View full syllabus

title: Math 6A
description: This course covers algebraic expressions and equations and computing with fractions and decimals. Students will learn to solve and write one-step equations and inequalities, multiply and divide fractions and mixed numbers, and convert fractions, decimals and percents. They will watch lesson videos and solve practice problems with each lesson. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Math 6B
description: This course covers ratios, rates, integers, four quadrants of the coordinate plane, 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional geometry and data/graphing. Students will learn real-world applications for ratios and rates, such as finding better buys, use knowledge of integers to graph in all four quadrants in a coordinate plane, and calculate area, surface area, and volume of geometric figures. They will end the semester with a survey project where they will gather data from other students, analyze the data, and display it in different graphs. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Social Studies 6A
description: This course covers early history through colonial history of the Western Hemisphere. Students will learn how to study history and geography. They will also learn about the earliest civilizations in the Americas with a focus on the United States, Canada, Latin America, and Mexico. They will create a family crest and take virtual tours as well as explore the holidays, national symbols, and foods of several countries. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. View full syllabus

title: Intro to Visual Arts
description: This course introduces students to the concepts and various media of visual arts. Students will learn the elements of art, the principles of design, various art techniques, and how to apply color theory and art criticism to evaluate art work. Students will need to procure an artist’s journal and various art supplies prior to the beginning of the course.  See the full syllabus here.

title: Business Computer Applications 1 with Google
description: Business Computer Applications 1 with Google is designed to equip students with essential digital skills in word processing, spreadsheets, presentations, and virtual meetings using Google Workspace. This course is a CTE Digital course and requires access to Google Applications. View full syllabus

title: Algebra 2A
description: Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. IDLA will provide the course content, Learning Management System, teachers, and internal support staff. Districts will provide local personnel to support the students with intervention support, social-emotional support, physical and/or virtual technical access to courses, and transcription of credits.  Lessons include graded learning activities integrated within the content and are worth 60% of the overall grade. Certified teachers check in on students frequently and attendance is recorded when a student logs in and completes some work each day. Finally, you will investigate the human body, perhaps the most complex of all living things on the Earth. What organs and organ systems make up the body; how do they function? title: Physical Science B - High School
description: Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. IDLA will provide the course content, Learning Management System, teachers, and internal support staff. Districts will provide local personnel to support the students with intervention support, social-emotional support, physical and/or virtual technical access to courses, and transcription of credits.  Lessons include graded learning activities integrated within the content and are worth 60% of the overall grade. Certified teachers check in on students frequently and attendance is recorded when a student logs in and completes some work each day. There is no high-stakes final exam; just shorter incremental exams in each unit that are worth 40% of the overall grade. Students must complete all exams to pass the course.  Course Description: Physical Science B is the second semester course designed to expose the student to the fundamentals of the nature of matter and the laws and theories that govern chemistry. In this course, students will spend time studying the building blocks of matter, how atoms form compounds, chemical reactions, and acid base theory. This course meets the Idaho State Standards for Physical Science. Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. The standards covered in this course are aligned to meet grades 9-12 physical science standards. Middle school students may find this course more rigorous than a traditional middle school course.  Click here to view full syllabus

Students will also apply the principles of this course to issues related to personal finance.  This one-semester course provides an overview of the basic principles of microeconomics and macroeconomics, including:  economic theory  supply, demand, and price  economic systems  business cycles  investments  the role of government  international trade  consumer choices  Click here to view full syllabus.

title: American Government A
description: Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. IDLA will provide the course content, Learning Management System, teachers, and internal support staff. Districts will provide local personnel to support the students with intervention support, social-emotional support, physical and/or virtual technical access to courses, and transcription of credits.  Lessons include graded learning activities integrated within the content and are worth 60% of the overall grade. Certified teachers check in on students frequently and attendance is recorded when a student logs in and completes some work each day. There is no high-stakes final exam; just shorter incremental exams in each unit that are worth 40% of the overall grade. Students must complete all exams to pass the course.  Course Description:  Welcome to American Government A! This course will help you meet your credit for American Government, required for graduation in Idaho. We will study forms of government and government theory, basics of the U.S. Constitution and American democracy, political parties and the electoral process, and the legislative branch. You will be challenged as you enjoy learning about our government and democracy.  Click here to view full syllabus.

title: American Government B
description: Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. IDLA will provide the course content, Learning Management System, teachers, and internal support staff. Districts will provide local personnel to support the students with intervention support, social-emotional support, physical and/or virtual technical access to courses, and transcription of credits.  Lessons include graded learning activities integrated within the content and are worth 60% of the overall grade. Certified teachers check in on students frequently and attendance is recorded when a student logs in and completes some work each day. There is no high-stakes final exam; just shorter incremental exams in each unit that are worth 40% of the overall grade. Students must complete all exams to pass the course.  Course Description:  Welcome to Government B! This course is the second semester of American Government required by the Idaho State Standards. We will learn more about the other two branches of government--the Executive and the Judicial. You will get to learn more about the federal and state government as we examine the many jobs of the president and the bureaucracy that affects our daily lives. We will also examine some of the many domestic and foreign policy matters that involve American citizens and foreign countries. The U.S. Court system helps us settle disputes and we will look at some of the landmark decisions that affect us all. The final section compares our government to other nations to see some of the differences in the rights of citizens and the different types of governments. Welcome aboard; let's get underway on our adventure in government!  Click here to view full syllabus.

title: AP U.S. Government & Politics A
description: This course is the first section of a two-section course and covers the required content and big ideas outlined in the AP Course and Exam Description (CED). These guidelines aim to provide students with a learning experience equivalent to most college level courses, as well as prepare individuals to pass the AP Exam. Students will learn about the constitutional system and political culture of the United States, study important foundational documents and Supreme Court cases, and develop skills to become a more informed citizen. They will demonstrate skills such as applying course concepts to a scenario, analyzing data, comparing Supreme Court cases, and using informed opinions to respond to argument essay prompts.  View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Sociology (CEI)
description: This introductory course presents the fundamental principles affecting human social systems. Emphasis is placed on the cultural and social forces governing groups and the conditions that transform social life, such as family, social change, social inequality, deviance, population, religion, culture, and the socialization process. Parents and students should review the syllabus content carefully prior to enrollment and determine if this content is in alignment with their beliefs, values, or principles.   This is a GEM: Social and Behavioral Ways of Knowing course. Full Syllabus  **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college.

title: Dual Credit US History 1 (CEI)
description: This course studies the United States history from is beginning to the Civil War. An emphasis will be place on the development of the American political system. Culture from the Colonial Period, Age of the Revolution, National Era and Jacksonian Period will also be considered.  This is a GEM: Social and Behavioral Ways of Knowing course. View full syllabus **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration.

title: Dual Credit US History 2 (CEI)
description: This course covers American history from 1877 to today through critical analysis, reading, writing, and communication skills. You’ll discover how decisions and events of the past continue to have profound effects on the world today and how history can influence future decisions. By the end of the course, you’ll be ready to put your knowledge to the test by weighing evidence and interpreting problems presented by historians. The equivalent of an introductory college level course, DC U.S. History offers students a chance to earn high school credit and college credit simultaneously, and opportunity for further study in history, political science, economics, sociology, and law.  This is a GEM: Social and Behavioral Ways of Knowing course. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Concepts of Biology A (CEI)
description: The Dual Credit Concepts of Biology course is a two-semester course equivalent to a college-level biology course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from the College of Eastern Idaho. Students must enroll in both DC BIO A and DC BIO B to earn credit from CEI.  This is an introductory course for non-science majors. An introduction to the principles and processes that apply to living systems will be investigated. Current biological issues will also be presented in this course.   This is a GEM Scientific Ways of Knowing course.   Idaho Lab High School Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View Full Syllabus  Required College Prerequisites:  HS Biology + 1 year other HS year of Science.

title: Dual Credit Concepts of Biology B (CEI)
description: The Dual Credit Biology course is a two semester course equivalent to a college level biology course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from College of Eastern Idaho. Students must enroll in both DC BIO A and DC BIO B to earn credit from CEI. This is an introductory course for non-science majors. An introduction to the principles and processes that apply to living systems will be investigated. Current biological issues will also be presented in this course.   This is a GEM Scientific Ways of Knowing course.   Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus  Required College Prerequisites:  HS Biology + 1 year other HS year of Science.

title: Dual Credit Precalculus 1: Algebra (CEI)
description: This course introduces functions and their graphs. Function notation, domain, range, composition, and inverses are covered. In addition, basic transformations of graphs as well as graphs of absolute value, quadratic, polynomial, radical, exponential, and logarithmic functions are included.  This is a GEM: Mathematical Way of Knowing course. Full Syllabus **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration.  Required College Prerequisites:  Algebra II and Proper College Placement Exam  To learn more about placement score requirements visit the CEI website.

title: Dual Credit Precalculus 2: Trigonometry (CEI)
description: This course is a study of circular function and right triangle approaches to trigonometry. Graphs of trigonometric functions, amplitude, frequency, and phase shifts are covered. Additional topics include trigonometric identities, inverse functions, and equations. *Not a GEM course. View Full Syllabus  Required College Prerequisites:  MATH 143 with a minimum grade of C or equivalent placement test score or PERM/INST.  **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college.

title: Dual Credit Introduction to Cybersecurity (CSI)
description: This course serves as a general introduction to the career of cybersecurity. Students will describe and demonstrate various aspects of the myriad of fields that make up cybersecurity. They will learn how to manage their own digital identity, and learn how to assess and manage risk. This course is part of a 3-course program at CSI. Students who take all 3 courses will receive a technical certificate. The three courses are Dual Credit Intro to Programming (CSI), Dual Credit Intro to Networking (CSI) and this course. Courses may be taken in any order. *Not a GEM course. View full syllabus  **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college. You must use the College Registration information found in this syllabus and register through the college separately. This syllabus includes policies for both Idaho Digital Learning Alliance and the cooperating university. Please be sure to review the entire syllabus.

title: Dual Credit Science of Animal Husbandry (U of I)
description: This course covers the study of Animal Science focused on animal husbandry, activities that are relevant to the production and care of these animals for human benefit. Students will learn about Maintaining Healthy Livestock, Sheep and Goats, Dairy Animals and Production, Nutrition and Feedstuffs, Genetics, Swine Production, Beef Production and Companion Animals and Other Production Livestock Species. They will complete projects, assignments, and practice a variety of topics in the field of animal science. This is a GEM course. Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course DOES NOT fulfill the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho. This course is considered an elective science course. This is a CTE Digital class. *Not a GEM course. View Full Syllabus

description: This course is a broad survey of mythologies from Western and Eastern world cultures. Students will analyze, discuss, and write about world mythologies and their relationship to contemporary culture. This is a GEM: Humanistic and Artistic Ways of Knowing Course. View full syllabus This course is a Quality Matters certified online course. Required College Prerequisites:  ENGL 101 Writing and Rhetoric I with a C- or better. This is a dual credit course. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you register with the university or college. title: Health - High School
description: Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. This course is designed to enhance the awareness and knowledge of healthy lifestyle choices. The lessons and activities are designed to introduce the student to important aspects of the main types of health: emotional and mental, social and consumer, and physical. Among other topics, students will explore nutrition, understanding and avoiding disease, first aid and CPR, and human sexuality. Several adolescent risk behaviors (dietary patterns that contribute to disease, sedentary lifestyles, sexual behaviors, tobacco, alcohol and drug use) will be addressed while advocating for the students to make healthy choices for their overall health. Students will find out about the components of a healthy lifestyle and ways to approach making healthy choices and decisions. All course materials are provided online.    The Idaho State Department of Education requires all public school students to be instructed in Hands-Only CPR as part of a health/ wellness course. This includes instruction and demonstration, as well as information on AED (Automated External Defibrillator). This course meets that requirement. View Full Syllabus

They will learn about the social, economical, and political characteristics in ancient Greece, Rome, the Byzantine Empire, early African and Mesoamerican civilizations. They will evaluate the role of the Catholic Church during the Middle Ages and determine the achievements of the Renaissance Era in order to explain how western society benefited from this Reformation. title: English 8A
description: Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. IDLA will provide the course content, Learning Management System, teachers, and internal support staff. Districts will provide local personnel to support the students with intervention support, social-emotional support, physical and/or virtual technical access to courses, and transcription of credits.  Lessons include graded learning activities integrated within the content and are worth 60% of the overall grade. Certified teachers check in on students frequently and attendance is recorded when a student logs in and completes some work each day. There is no high-stakes final exam; just shorter incremental exams in each unit that are worth 40% of the overall grade. Students must complete all exams to pass the course.  Course Description: This is the first semester of a two-semester English 8 course that aligns with the Idaho Core standards. In this dynamic class, students will embark on an exploration of sustainability, honing their research skills along the way and strengthening their investigative know-how. Their journey with nonfiction text will continue by reading the thought-provoking Undefeated: Jim Thorpe and the Carlisle Indian School Football Team by Steve Sheinkin, set in the 1830s. Finally, students will tackle the question of whether contact sports are worth the risk, constructing persuasive arguments supported by concrete evidence. Prepare to embark on a journey of discovery, critical thinking, and self-expression in this enriching English course. View full syllabus

title: English 8B
description: Credit Recovery Course Overview:  Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. IDLA will provide the course content, Learning Management System, teachers, and internal support staff. Districts will provide local personnel to support the students with intervention support, social-emotional support, physical and/or virtual technical access to courses, and transcription of credits.  Lessons include graded learning activities integrated within the content and are worth 60% of the overall grade. Certified teachers check in on students frequently and attendance is recorded when a student logs in and completes some work each day. There is no high-stakes final exam; just shorter incremental assessments in each unit that are worth 40% of the overall grade. Students must complete all unit assessments to pass the course.  Course Description:  This is the second semester of a two semester English 8 course that aligns to the Idaho Core standards. The course is focused on responding to change, beginning with a look at the literary genre of drama while reading the play Trifles. Students will study how to understand and write strong arguments, structuring their writing around the claim and counterclaim. Students will have the option to select one of three novels to read and consider what it means to be free.Throughout the course, students will investigate questions such as, What is the purpose of drama?, What is my responsibility as a citizen of the world?, How do I form my own opinions in the midst of so much information?, How does literature help me to better understand how to deal with change in my life?, and How do I defend my opinion against other opinions? View full syllabus

title: Personal Finance
description: This CTE course covers the basics of personal finance to put the student on the road to becoming financially savvy. Students will learn about consumer rights and responsibilities, smart ways to spend, save, and use credit, as well as keeping their assets safe and finding a way to finance a post secondary education. This class meets the Idaho core competencies in financial literacy for graduation. This is a CTE Digital class. Syllabus link

title: Business Computer Applications 1 with Google - FX
description: Business Computer Applications 1 with Google is designed to equip students with essential digital skills in word processing, spreadsheets, presentations, and virtual meetings using Google Workspace. Through hands-on learning with Docs, Sheets, Slides, and Meet, students will engage in practical, real-world projects that prepare them for both academic success and the demands of the modern workplace. This course is a CTE Digital course and requires access to Google Applications. View full syllabus

title: Fashion and Textiles
description: Do you have a flair for fashion? If so, the fashion industry might just be for you! In this course, you'll explore career possibilities and look into professional organizations. You will learn about the basic principles of design. You will also develop the essential marketing and communication skills that build success in any business. This is a CTE Digital class. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Introduction to Networking (CSI)
description: This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college. You must use the College Registration information found in this syllabus and register through the college separately. This syllabus includes policies for both Idaho Digital Learning Alliance and the cooperating university. Please be sure to review the entire syllabus.    This course prepares students with the knowledge and skills necessary to manage, maintain, troubleshoot, install, operate, and configure basic network infrastructure; describe networking technologies and basic design principles; adhere to wiring standards; and use testing tools. This course prepares students to take the CompTIA Network+ certification exam.   This course is part of a 3-course program at CSI. Students who take all 3 courses will receive a technical certificate. The three courses are Dual Credit Intro to Programming (CSI), Dual Credit Intro to Cybersecurity (CSI) and this course. Courses may be taken in any order. *Not a GEM course. View Full Syllabus

title: Survey of World Mythology
description: This course covers mythologies from around the world. Students will learn to better understand people and cultures from Egypt and the Middle East to North and Central America. They will compare common elements in mythologies around the world and create their own mythology with similar elements. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.  View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Chemistry A (CEI)
description: The Dual Credit Chemistry course is a two semester course equivalent to a college level chemistry course. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from College of Eastern Idaho. Students must enroll in both DC Chem A and DC Chem B to earn credit from CEI. This is an introductory chemistry course that helps prepare students to understand how chemistry impacts the world around us. Topics can include: An introduction to scientific thought, the importance of measurement systems, the organization of matter, chemical bonding, the nature of carbon/air/water, chemical reactions, acids/bases, as well as others. This is a dual credit class for non-science majors. This class will not count towards a STEM degree. It is intended for students wanting to register for university credit.This is a GEM: Scientific Way of Knowing course.   Idaho High School Lab Science Requirement: This course fulfills the high school lab science requirement by the State of Idaho in that there are weekly opportunities to manipulate equipment, materials, specimens or develop skills in observation and analysis and discover, demonstrate, illustrate or test scientific principles or concepts. View full syllabus

Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn college credits from College of Eastern Idaho. This course is a GEM course. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Government and Politics A (CEI)
description: This introductory course provides a study of the foundation of the United States government and the evolution of constitutional principles. Special attention is given to the three branches of national government, powers and the limits of national government, state's rights and local control, public ethics, political parties, voters, pressure groups, civil liberties and civil rights, and public opinion. Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn  college credits from College of Eastern Idaho. Students must enroll in both Gov & Pol A  and Gov & Pol B to earn credit from CEI. This course will also satisfy Idaho graduation  requirements. This is a GEM: Social and Behavioral Ways of Knowing course. View full syllabus

title: Dual Credit Government and Politics B (CEI)
description: This introductory course provides a study of the foundation of the United States government and the evolution of constitutional principles. Special attention is given to the three branches of national government, powers and the limits of national government, state's rights and local control, public ethics, political parties, voters, pressure groups, civil liberties and civil rights, and public opinion.  Students enrolled in the Dual Credit course will earn  college credits from College of Eastern Idaho. Students must enroll in both Gov A and  Gov B to earn credit from CEI. This course will also satisfy Idaho graduation  requirements. This is a GEM: Social and Behavioral Ways of Knowing course. View full syllabus

title: English as a New Language 1 - FX
description: This course is designed for the rapid mastery of the English language fundamentals, which focus on: reading, writing, speaking, language, and listening skills. Students will learn academic vocabulary, how to speak to teachers and peers about common school and community topics, and will learn about the culture and customs of the United States as they relate to the academic needs of high school. They will complete units covering the alphabet, verbal introductions, reading and grammar, and numbers including time, calendars, money, basic math computation and application. Students will also learn to speak and listen for common phrases and language to support participation and success at school. View Full Syllabus

title: English as a New Language 2 - FX
description: This course is designed for the rapid mastery of the English language fundamentals, which focus on: reading, writing, speaking, language, and listening skills. Students will learn academic vocabulary, how to speak to teachers and peers about common school and community topics, and will learn about the culture and customs of the United States as they relate to the academic needs of high school. They will complete a review of verbal introductions, pronunciation practice of common consonant blends and vowel teams, as well as discuss and create projects applying beginning to intermediate forms of language used within the contexts of math, social studies, science and English language arts. View Full Syllabus

title: Exploring STEM Careers with iPads - High School
description: In this project-based course, students will learn about different opportunities in STEM career fields while exercising their creativity by completing an array of projects on an iPad from the Everyone Can Create curriculum curated by Apple. Students will learn about the skills, work experience, requirements, and benefits of popular science, technology, engineering, and math careers. Some careers students will explore include forensic science, aerospace engineering, and sports analytics. Students will demonstrate their understanding of different STEM careers by completing projects on an iPad such as creating an infographic, podcast, short film, and more. This course is a Quality Matters-certified online course. View full syllabus

title: American Sign Language 2A
description: This course covers vocabulary, ASL syntax and grammar, culture/history, and notable Deaf individuals for students continuing in American Sign Language (ASL). Students will learn and practice concepts such as Classifiers, Signer’s Perspective, Order of Description, Technology for the deaf, and professions within the Deaf community. They will collaborate with other ASL students using a variety of methods including discussions and videos, as well as explore some accomplishments of Deaf individuals. View full syllabus

title: Science of Forensics
description: This course explores the fascinating world of the scientific study of forensics. Students will apply multiple science disciplines, such as life science, biology, physics, and chemistry, to forensic investigations. Students will analyze crime scenes, apply investigation techniques, and draw conclusions from evidence. They will gain hands-on experience, enhance critical thinking, and develop problem-solving skills.   Idaho Lab Science Requirement: This course DOES fulfill the lab science requirement by the State of Idaho. This course is a Quality Matters certified online course.   NOTE: This course exposes students to sensitive topics such as homicide, death, blood, weapons, etc. It may not be suitable for all audiences. View Syllabus

title: Native American History
description: This course covers the history of Indigenous Peoples of North and South America from Pre-Columbian times through modern day. Students will learn about the impact that European colonies had on Indigenous Peoples. They will also explore the lifestyle changes that have occurred to Indigenous Peoples throughout the centuries as well as the current issues facing today’s tribes. View full syllabus

title: Lifetime Fitness - Middle School
description: This course covers participating in, analyzing, and learning about new ways to be physically active in a fun, creative way. Students will learn about health-related and skill-related fitness components and explore innovative yet structured ways to set goals, reflect on their personal performance levels, and push themselves to new limits. They will end the course with a culminating project that allows them to combine their new fitness-related knowledge with their own goals, research, interests, and imagination! This course is a Quality Matters-certified online course. Syllabus

title: Esports 1
description: This course covers the history, evolution, and current state of the esports industry and competitive gaming. Students will learn a brief history of esports, tracing its evolution and the impact of technological advancements, leading to its current prominence. They will gain insights into collegiate esports and its connection to academic pursuits. Detailed game analysis will teach students how to dissect gameplay strategies and roles, while a look at esports research and the future will provide a glimpse into ongoing industry trends. They will learn about specific game genres - MOBAs and shooters, as well as sports and cards - highlighting their significance as esports. They will explore the complexities of gaming culture and toxicity. Students will study esports team and player management, understand the roles of coaches and players, and explore player wellness routines. Throughout the course, students will engage in discussions, complete game analyses, create esports research projects, and analyze the real-world strategies of professional esports companies and athletes, preparing them for a well-rounded understanding of this evolving industry.   This course offers students a hands-on experience of four major esports game genres - MOBAS, Shooters, Sports, and Cards. Prior to these gameplay assignments, students will receive guidance on safely registering for and participating in these games. It's important to note that all selected games have undergone a thorough vetting process through the IDLA app review system, ensuring they are safe, secure, and suitable for those aged 13 and above. We emphasize responsible gaming practices, by providing students with information on online gaming risks, the importance of taking breaks, and the fundamental principle of enjoying the learning process. The course structure is built on valuable input from a survey of district tech directors statewide, and it adheres to a well-defined curriculum with explicit learning objectives aligned with standards, employing a performance-based grading system to assess student progress. This course is a Quality Matters-certified online course.  View Full Syllabus

title: Beginning Ukulele
description: This course covers the basics of playing a ukulele and will have absolute beginners with no prior music experience playing full-length versions of their favorite songs by the end of it. Students will need to provide their own tuner and ukulele to use in this course, but there is no need to fret about these items before class begins. (Pun intended.) At the beginning of the course, students will learn how to choose a tuner and ukelele that are right for them.  Once students can properly hold and tune their ukuleles, they will strum along with popular songs, compose their own melodies, learn how to read tablature, and play basic chords and chord progressions. Booming with opportunities to pick up their ukes and jam, this course will leave budding musicians equipped with the routine practice, foundational knowledge, and core techniques needed to continue on their musical journeys. View full syllabus

title: Speech
description: Credit recovery courses include a daily attendance requirement in addition to asynchronous instruction to provide students with a high level of learning. IDLA will provide the course content, Learning Management System, teachers, and internal support staff. Districts will provide local personnel to support the students with intervention support, social-emotional support, physical and/or virtual technical access to courses, and transcription of credits. Lessons include graded learning activities integrated within the content and are worth 60% of the overall grade. Certified teachers check in on students frequently and attendance is recorded when a student logs in and completes some work each day. There is no high-stakes final exam; just shorter incremental assessments in each unit that are worth 40% of the overall grade. Students must complete all unit assessments to pass the course.  Course Description:  This course emphasizes the basic principles of effective communication and public speaking skills. Students will present an Informative Speech. Projects and activities will focus on Idaho Core standards and emphasize listening, speaking, viewing, collaborating, comprehending, presenting, and attaining knowledge and ideas. **The Informative Speech presentation is required in order for students to be eligible to pass the course, regardless of their overall grade. View Full Syllabus

title: Chip, Chip, Hooray! Semiconductors 1
description: This course covers the foundations of semiconductor science and technology. Students will learn what semiconductors are, where they are used in Idaho and beyond, how to build basic circuits, and what careers are possible in the semiconductor industry. They will explore industry innovations and manufacturing, trace paths to reach career goals in the semiconductor industry, and investigate the future of semiconductor science through team challenges and gamified learning explorations. This course is a Quality Matters-certified online course. Link to Syllabus

title: Officiating Youth Sports
description: Officiating Youth Sports is a comprehensive course designed for high school students interested in the multifaceted world of sports officiating. This course offers the essentials of officiating various sports, including wrestling, football, basketball, volleyball, soccer, baseball, and softball. It's structured to provide students with both theoretical knowledge and practical skills necessary for becoming competent and confident sports officials. In this course, students will select three sports to learn to officiate. They will have the opportunity to take the national certification exam for at least one of their chosen sports. A background check is mandatory to become a certified official. This course is a Quality Matters-certified online course. View Full Syllabus

title: Dual Credit Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering (BSU): Semiconductors 2
description: **This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. This means that you can receive both college credit and high school credit on 2 separate transcripts if you complete registration with the university or college. You must use the College Registration information found in this syllabus and register through the college separately. This syllabus includes policies for both Idaho Digital Learning Alliance and the cooperating university. Please be sure to review the entire syllabus.   Course Description:  This course provides an introduction to electrical and computer engineering hardware and software tools. This includes an overview of the electrical and computer engineering profession, careers, and foundations for success in the curriculum. Students will design and build a project to provide hands-on experience. The course includes an introduction to skills for college success. Syllabus

title: Math Level-Up Lab 1 (4 unit)
description: This course covers the 4th, and 5th-grade place value, decimal operations and measurement assessment targets of the ISAT and the Idaho Content Standards. Students will learn place value, computation with decimals, and the metric and US systems of Measurement. They will complete lessons and assignments to help strengthen and improve math skills. This course is a Quality Matters-certified online course. View Full Syllabus

title: Dual Credit Introduction to Art (LCSC)
description: This course is an interdisciplinary consideration of the historical sequence of art styles; slides, lectures, and discussions of architecture, painting, sculpture, and other arts are seen from the viewpoints of the philosopher, the artist, and the layperson. This course is a college-level course that uses a college-adopted textbook, content, and assessments that may discuss sensitive issues. Parents and students should review the syllabus content carefully prior to enrollment and determine if this content is in alignment with their beliefs, values, or principles. Full syllabus **GEM course: Humanistic & Artistic Ways of Knowing  This is a dual credit course. There are two separate registration processes for this course: an IDLA registration & the college registration. You must use the College Registration information found in this syllabus and register through the college separately. title: Algebra 1A - FX Pilot
description: This course will deepen and extend understanding of linear and exponential  relationships by contrasting them with each other and by applying linear models to data  that exhibit a linear trend, and students engage in methods for analyzing, solving, and  using quadratic functions. The completion of this course will prepare students to  continue on to the second semester of Algebra 1, and then on to Algebra 2 or  Geometry. View full syllabus
